t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[57]: Record your subject with the light source directly on the subject.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[8]:: Your story will be more interesting if you interview characters with opposing viewpoints.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[52]: Use follow-up questions if you need more information.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[60]: Low light can produce poor shots. Shooting outside or in a sunny room can give you great light.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[21]: Shoot different size shots to create an effective sequence.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[43]: Make sure your subject is in focus and not distorted by something in the frame.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[42]: Hold your device close to the subject, and just below their mouth.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[12]: Ensure the most important part of your shot fills at least 50% of the frame.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[17]: "If your picture's not good enough, you're not close enough." -Robert Capa
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[40]: Listen for background noise that may harm the quality of your story before you click record.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[67]: A good series should be made up of five strong images. If you have more good shots, add them in though.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[37]: Ask only one question at a time.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[29]: Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not record everything you hear.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[63]: Every story has a major question. What's the question you've answered at the end of your item?
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[56]: Machines make a lot of noise, turn them off if possible, or change your location if you can.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[24]: Check your audio level using headphones before you start recording.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[69]: Tell us how the issue is changing in response to the actions of characters in the story.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[16]: Do not place your subject in the center of the frame, use the rule of thirds.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[68]: Tell us some interesting facts about the history of the issue or why it started.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[34]: Be clear about your topic or goal when requesting an interview.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[18]: Keep recording for at least 15 seconds, if the clip is too long, trim it.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[50]: Keep the conversation moving. Ask: Why? What happened next? What do you mean?
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[51]: If your questions do not provide a satisfactory answer, change your approach.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[13]: Combine clips of different sizes or types to create a complementary sequence.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[31]: When recording an interview, prepare at least 15 questions.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[48]: If it is windy, point your camera away from the wind, or block if with your body or a wall.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[38]: Ask hard questions, but remember to be polite. A polite request will go a long way.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[1]:: When shooting in dangerous situations always have an exit strategy.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[64]: A climax is the answer on the question that keeps your listener listening. Don't give it away too early.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[25]: Use multiple sources of audio to tell your story.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[20]: To shoot a sequence you need to break down the elements of your story into individual shots.

t_news_library::text_card_0::text: News Reports are driven by the reporter, most often using their own voice. In this kind of story the reporter takes us on a journey through the issue, either talking on camera or with a voice over. In the best narrated stories the reporter does more than just explain the story. The reporter creates drama through how he or she organizes and narrates the material. Reports can be audio or video stories.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[70]: Tell us what is expected for the issue in the future.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[9]:: End the interview by asking, "Is there anything else you would like to add?"
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[61]: Lights approximately 3 feet away from your character are the most flattering.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[35]: Be calm. Relaxing will help your interview subject relax too.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[30]: Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not shoot everything you see.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[59]: If you can feel the light source on the back of your neck on a sunny day, you will have the best lighting in that situation.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[10]: Well composed shots have space in the direction the subject is facing, or moving.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[45]: Don't hold your breath, set your shot, and breathe. When your shot is steady, begin recording
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[6]:: Get to the most important question quickly in the interview.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[3]:: Have a one-sentence explanation of your story for your characters.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[14]: Do not stop recording until the action in your shot is complete.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[15]: Start the camera rolling before the action begins and don't stop recording until after it ends.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[62]: Sound is half of the information in a video, consider it for every shot.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[2]:: Do some research before the interview when possible. You will ask better, more relevant questions.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[26]: Find different sounds and quotes that help tell your story.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[23]: Hit record before you ask a question to record a few seconds of silence before speaking.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[53]: Remember, without good sound your images only tell half the story.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[39]: Courtesy can help establish trust and improve your interviews.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[66]: Ask yourself for every clip: does it tell me something new?
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[41]: When preparing to record, hold your device in a way that is comfortable and natural.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[7]:: In your interview, remember to be tough but fair.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[19]: Always update your White Balance setting when you move to a different lighting situation.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[36]: Always know what you want from the interview.
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[11]: "The size of an object in the frame should equal it's importance at that moment." -Alfred Hitchcock
t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[44]: Decide the best place to record from and hold your frame in place until complete.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[33]: Record first hand observations and interviews whenever possible.

t_news_library::tip_collection::tips[4]:: Save sensitive questions for the end.
